data.title: Turkish Camel Corps
data.meta_description: I was wondering if there was a Turkish/Ottoman equivalent to the Imperial Camel Corps? If so are their any bilbliographical references for them and where they operated? Did they use Beduoin recruits or Beduoin levies to patrol desert areas?
data.text:
Thanks for the replies, I was idly gazing at my book shelf and saw my copy of the Handbook of the Turkish Army 1916 (doh! what a great memory I have!)

A quick flick through the OOB came up with the following:

VIIIth army corps:

Corps troops:

Camel Corps (battalion 600 strong) (3 Camel Corps battalions have been formed, one (600 men) reaching Baghdad in September [1915], another in November. The third, composed of adventurers of all (Moslem) nationalities, at Bir es Saba in January 1916.

These troops were arbitrarily numbered by the British as:

Camel Battalion No.1; Formed in the winter of 1914-15. Engaged on the canal, March-may 1915. Arrived at Baghdad, September 1915 (See above).

Camel Battalion No.2 O.C. Ali Pasha. Arrived at Baghdad, November 1915 (See above)

Camel Battalion No.3: 'The Moslem adventurers' (See above).

It also mentions Camel Corps troops in Arabia but I can't find them in the OOB. (probably gone blind stupid again!)

Any further elaboration of this would be great

Its funny you should mention this piture.

During my reseach for a book on the Camel Corps I have received many photos from relatives of soldiers who served there.

These photos are of the soldier and or his mates mounted on camels most often in front of the pryimids.

Now a closer look shows they are in fact not Camel Corps soldiers, just a soldier on a camel, a photo that was taken in there thousands since then to now.

I beleive you can still get this done if you go there.

So I always look for some provernace on the photos now before taking them as a Came Corps soldier.

S.B

Ferreted out some more info. on the Camel Corps

David Nicolle in his Osprey book "Lawrence and the Arab Revolts" p.4

'When the Ottoman army made its thrust against the Suez Canal early in 1915 it did so with a force of only 20,000 men, including two companies of the largely Arab Ottoman Camel Corps under Sami Bey........The Ottomans attempted another advance in the spring of 1916 during which the Camel Corps performed well, capturing a substantial part of a British cavalry regiment at outposts of Qatiya and Ughratina on 23 April.'

I presume the the battalion involved at Qatiya was Camel Battalion No.3 'The Moslem Adventurers' since the other 2 battalions were redeployed to Baghdad in late 1915. Michael's photograph may therefore be of the Camel Battalion No.3.

This may also be the battalion from which the Arabs switched sides to the Hashemite forces during the Arab Revolt to form the Camel Corps of the Northern Arab Army(?)

Mate,

As you can see time has gone on since this was first started.

Yes the Ottomans raised at lest four Camel Regts during the war.

These were all mixed up and had a mixed history due to the lack of suitable riding camels.

As I said at lest four Camel Regt raised, these are possibly;

Along with these four Regts were a number of native/arab camel units raised localy, like;

Hejaz Arab (Akendji) Camel Regt + 2 Camel Co + 6x guns 8th FAR at Katya April 1916

Sham Camel Yeman Bir Raha district Shammar Camel corps (arabs) Shammar Camel corps (arabs) Shammar Arabs (300 men)

As I said most Camel units were at times without enough animals to ride, like at Rafa, where most of the Camel Troops were dismounted due to the lack of riding camels.

"The Turkish garrison at Rafa under Lieutenant Colonel Ismail Hakki Bey commanding the 31st Infantry Regiment consisted of his own 1st and 2nd Battalions 31st Infantry Regiment, 3rd Division (less the 5th and 7th Companies), including around 6 to 10 MG's from the MG Companies of the 31st Regiment and the 80th Regiment (less gun or guns lost at Magdhaba) and a mixed MG Company from the 3rd Cavalry Division, a Turkish camel Corps platoon and dismounted Camel Company (200 men), a Gendarme Company (30 men) and part of a hospital unit. The force was supported by four mountain guns of the 8th mountain Battery 1st Artillery Regiment,"

Most ORbats for the Ottomans in Palestine list Camel Troops, but never in large numbers and mostly attached to the 3rd Cavalry Div like;

Battles around Murat River on July-Sep.1916 at the order of 4th AC of 2nd Army Feb 1917- 6th Cav Regt + 7th Cav Regt (500 men + 8xguns) + 1-3/138th Regt 138th MG Co (3rd Div) (1500 men) 8th Cav Regt det - shown March 1917 Allied reports 1st Gaza 3rd Cav Div 6th Cav Regt 8th Cav Regts (1500 men 11 guns) (shown in Turkish reported 138th Regt) + (arrived after battle) 125th Regt (2500 men 6 MG's) - shown on orbat 6th Cav Regt & 8th Cav Regt att 2nd Regt (for fighting at Es Salt) May 1918 - shown June 1917 Allied reports (1800 Cav 14 MG's) + Camel Co (150 men) + Mule Mounted Regt (500 men) - shown Oct 1917 Allied reports 6th Cav Regt (500 men 8 MG's) 8th Cav Regt (500 men 8 MG's) (7th Cav Regt + Bty 4 guns T/det to Arabia) att 125th Regt (16th Div) 650 men? 12 MGs including 8 x Lewis guns) - shown Oct 1917 3rd Cav Div had 16 MG's (6th Cav Regt 8 MGs 8th Cav Regt 8 MGs) - shown Turkish Oct 1917 reports 3rd Cav Div (1800 men 16 Mgs 4 guns) - shown Jan 1918 Allied reports (1350 cav 24 Mgs) + 7th Cav Regt (650 cav 8 MGs) - shown Feb 1918 Allied reports (1000 cav 26 MGs) 6th Cav Regt 8th Cav Regt 1Co Camel Corps (100 men) + 701st (30 cav) & 702nd (30 cav) Cav Troops - shown March 1918 Allied reports (650 cav 19 MGs) 6th Cav Regt 8th Cav Regt 1Co Camel Corps (100 men) - shown April 1918 Allied reports (500 cav 12 MGs) + Camel Co (100 men) entioned att 145th Regt - shown May 1918 Allied reports - (600 cav 19 MG's) + Camel Co (100 men) + 7th Cav Regt (350 cav 8 Mgs) - shown June 1918 Allied reports 6th Cav 8th Cav Regts (600 cav 100 men 16 MGs) - shown July 1918 Allied reports 6th Cav Regt 8th Cav Regts (600 cav 16 MG's) + Camel Co (100 men) - shown Aug 1918 Allied reports 6th Cav Regt 8th Cav Regts (600 cav 16 MG's) Mule Mtn Regt & Camel Co (375 men) - shown Sept 1918 Allied reports 6th Cav Regt (300 men 8 Mgs) 8th Cav Regt (380 men 8 Mgs) + camel Co (100 men) - shown Oct 1918 Allied reports PoW commanders 6th Cav and 8th Cav Regts

2 hours ago, stevebecker said:

Again some how I picked up a photo?

Well, I uploaded it while writing the post, and somehow it popped up to you yet again. It's odd to see your image used in somebody's post before you share it. Anyway

Ottoman Camel Corps (Hecinsüvar / Camel rider) was quite an interesting class in Ottoman army. They wore unique, cool looking, historical type of uniforms, probably nicked from those of old Ottoman light cavalry sub-class called "Akincilar" (raiders) which was active in 14th-16th centuries. They're also usually wore a cap badge (a crescent) which was an exceptional thing in Ottoman army. Their distinctive collar color was white, same as ordinary cavalry. Sadly, there's little or no study on these guys.

The most famous soldier from Ottoman Hecinsüvar units was Lt. Halet (b.1895). He was killed during the unsuccessful attack on Dueidar, which was held mainly by 5/Royal Scots Fusiliers, in Battle of Katia. A wonderful example of Ottoman hecinsüvar uniforms in this photo of him below (Photo source: Tasvir-i Efkar Magazine):

Group of officers from 1st Hecinsüvar Regiment or Medina Hecinsüvar Regiment operating in Hedjaz. Regt commander Maj. Mehmet Atif in the middle.
